rooms.Name: Building HQ
rooms.Description:
This room is filled with building supplies of every sort, ranging from 2 by
4's and nails, to construction paper and Elmer's Glue. Power tools,
screwdrivers, and blueprints are strewn about in what appears to be
contructive disarray.
   A small notepad rests on a sofa, keeping track of building projects.

rooms.Name: Player One's Library
rooms.Description:
You are standing amid a huge pile if giant game cards. All the cards are
face-down, as if waiting for someone to draw one. Out of curiosity, you lift
the edge of one, and look at it. On the face of the card, there is a depiction
of a spell, and it's cost in mana, but it's unlike any mana you've ever heard
of. The mana is divided into different colors, and it takes a lot less of it
to cast spells than it does in the "real" world. Whoever is playing this game
seems to be some sort of deluded, wanna-be wizard.

rooms.Name: In Player One's Hand
rooms.Description:
You are standing in mid-aid, behind a wall of giant cards, each depicting a
different spell. On the face of each card is a fanciful depiction of the
spell's effect, and some information about how the spell is used in the game.
You wonder what's behind the wall of cards, and decide to peek around it.
   You gasp in awe of the scene spread out beneath you. The landscape below is
twisted and mottled with terrains from every part of the multiverse, brought
here by the titanic magic of the players' spells. The boundaries of the lands
are quite distinct, as the landscape changes abruptly where one spell's effect
ends and another begins.
   Creatures of every description wander this surreal landscape, some
magnificent, others horrible. You are fascinated by the scene, and are
severely tempted to go down and explore.
   Far off in the distance, you notice another wall of cards hanging in the
air, with the reverse sides facing you.

rooms.Name: Player One's Graveyard
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what in game terms could be considered a discard pile.
From your point of view, it's a combination graveyard, junkyard.
   All around you are the twisted and mutilated remains of conjured creatures,
the shards of shattered artifacts, and the burnt out husks of used-up
enchanments (don't ask what the husk of an enchantment looks like).
   As you watch, one of the creatures begins to glow with a pale white light,
and begin to reform. In moments, it it whole again, and journeys off to heed
its master's call and live again.

rooms.Name: Necropolis
rooms.Description:
You are standing in a ghost town, or, to be more precise, a city of the
dead. All the buildings are in a state of disrepair and decay, and the streets
are nearly deserted. You wish they were completely deserted, as the only
residents appear to be the shades of the dead. While they don't seem to be
hostile toward you, it's still unnerving to see ghost going about their daily
routines as if they didn't know they were dead.

rooms.Name: Tundra
rooms.Description:
This cold and barren plain could have been summoned from the northlands of
any one of a thousand worlds. The tundra is a harsh climate, but a common
enough one. Normally you would expect to see tunra wolves, or elk, but it
seems that in summoning the land, the wizard did not summon the inhabitants.

rooms.Name: Underground River
rooms.Description:
You duck your head as you enter this tunnel that the swift flowing river has
carved in the underground caverns. You are careful to stay on the banks of the
river, as stepping into it would cause you to be washed downstream to
who-knows-where (especially in this insane world).
   Off to the east you tink you can make out the sounds of a waterfall over
the rush of the running water.

rooms.Name: Underground Sea
rooms.Description:
You're on the shore of a vast underground sea, which is being fed by a
waterfall, crashing down from the west. Oddly, you can still see, though it is
dim. The ceiling of this cavern is covered in phosphorescent moss. The sea
stretches on to the south for farther than you can see in the gloom, but
tunnels lead out in other directions.

rooms.Name: City of Brass
rooms.Description:
Will wonders never cease?! This entire city is made out of brass! Styled in
ancient Arabian fashion, with bulbous spires that taper to a delicate point,
and merchant stalls filled with exotic fruits, every building is made of
brass. The streets are paved in brass, and nearly every object you see has
been crafted from brass. Once you get over the overzealous devotion to a
single theme, you notice how beautiful this place actually is.

rooms.Name: Scrubland
rooms.Description:
This place is pathetic. The land is flat, and rocky, and almost nothing is
growing here. What does grow consists mostly of hardy weeds, and scrub
grasses. You can't be certain if this land was ruined by the wizards' spells,
or if it was brought here in this condition to serve some purpose that is
beyond your understanding.

rooms.Name: The Tabernacle at Pendrel Vale
rooms.Description:
Before you is some sort of holy citadel. While the entrance is barred and
warded against intruders, you can still see the tabernacle, and remark at its
magnificence. The place seems to give off some sort of aura that makes you
feel a bit weak. The aura seems to have a more pronounced effect on the
summoned creatures around you, as they shun this place. You should be safe
from them as long as you remain in this haven.

rooms.Name: The Abyss
rooms.Description:
This is the most evil of all planes. whatever wizard conjured up this small
part of the Abyss must be powerful indeed! As you watch, some poor creature
wanders too close to this place, and gets sucked into oblivion. This
demi-plane must have been created to get rid of the excess creatures wandering
around. It's unlikely that the wizards consider you any different from their
minions...better leave before one of them decides you've grown to be too much
trouble.

rooms.Name: Sunken City
rooms.Description:
Plunging underwater, you see a vast city, submerged, and hidden from the
eyes of surface-dwellers. Buildings and columns are in perfect condition,
aside from being a bit wet and covered in kelp. You have to wonder whether
this city was built here by some aquatic race of beings, or sank beneath the
waves when some catastrophe ended a surface civilization.

rooms.Name: Circle of Protection
rooms.Description:
Drawn on the ground here, is a large, ornate circle, decorated with runes,
and powders, precious metals. While you can't be certain, you suspect that the
circle is meant to protect casters from beings that they have summoned. If
that's true, that means that this is some sort of summoning area.

rooms.Name: Nether Void
rooms.Description:
This is a place of magic far greater than any you could ever hope to
control. The very wind of this blackened void seems to strip you of power. The
thought of staying in this place for any length of time seems unwise, as you
cannot defend yourself here, and who knows what powerful beings may still hold
their powers here.

rooms.Name: Heaven's Gate
rooms.Description:
You are standing before a set of huge, golden gates, set into a wall of
puffy white clouds. The gates have swung partly open, and radiant golden light
is pouring out, too blinding in its glory for you to see beyond the gates. If
you had your geuss, this would be the entrance to heaven, from where a good
wizard might summon angels and the like.

rooms.Name: Field of Dreams
rooms.Description:
You are standing in a pleasant field. All around you, you see the faces of
people you know, and dreams you thought you had forgotten. You begin to relax,
but then realize that that's probably why this place was created, to put you
off your guard.

rooms.Name: Spiritual Sanctuary
rooms.Description:
Marble columns support a high ceiling in this chamber. In the center of the
room is a pool of soothing, warm water, where one could relax, with steps
leading down into it. The air is fresh and sweet-smelling, and a sense of
calmness pervades the atmosphere. This would seem the perfect place to
meditate and heal.

rooms.Name: Gate to Phyrexia
rooms.Description:
Stepping through a rusted iron gate, you instantly feel a light rain falling
on you. Sighing at your miserable luck at being caught in the middle of a
storm, you look up at the murky brown, polluted clouds, and get a drop of
grease in your eye for your trouble. It's raining grease! As you wonder what
sort of twisted world you've wandered into, you notice that this place is some
sort of industrial nightmare. Broken machines litter the ground as gremlins
tear them apart. Thick smoke pours out of buildings that you can only assume
of be factories.

rooms.Name: Mirror Universe
rooms.Description:
You are standing in a bare chamber now, with the only feature being a
full-length wall mirror. As you regard your reflection in the mirror, you
notice that the reflection shows a different landscape than the one sprawled
out behind you. Comparing the views behind you and in the mirror, you notice
that the creatures in both are the same, but the mirror seems to be showing a
scene from a parellel universe.

rooms.Name: Arena of the Ancients
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what must once have been a gladitoial arena...thousands
of years ago. Though the staggered rings of stone seats for the spectators
still remain, the columns that no doubt once supported grans architectural
works are now crumbling. The arena floor is just dirt, but is remarkably
cleared of debris. Perhaps this place is still used for its ancient purpose.

rooms.Name: Sorrow's Path
rooms.Description:
You are walking the bleakest path you have ever passed. Decorating the road
are clay statues of people wailing in despair and agony, and there is no
vegetation around. You want to leave this place as soon as you can, before the
effects start to rub off on you.

Exits.Description: You can see a pathway into darkness below.

rooms.Name: Mishra's Workshop
rooms.Description:
You are outside some sort of twisted factory. You can't tell if it is made
of iron, or the flesh of some foul beast, but it seems to be almost alive.
There is a reddish glow coming from the eye-like windows, and the smoke from
the chimneys comes at regular intervals, like breathing.

rooms.Name: Obelisk of Undoing
rooms.Description:
The ground here is sharp and rocky, and completely devoid of life.
Strangely, you don't get the feeling that this place is deserted. The huge,
ornate, stone obelisk seems to be the only thing that should be here, and you
wonder why...

rooms.Name: Land's Edge
rooms.Description:
You've never gone in for the theory that the world is flat, but this place
seems to confirm it. You have reached the land's edge, and can look out over
into the vast oblivion beyond. You watch as bits of the edge shimmer, then
crumble, and the wizards harness the power of the land here.

rooms.Name: Caverns of Despair
rooms.Description:
Entering the caverns, you are overcome by despair. No matter how many
companions you have, you feel utterly alone. The only hope you still have is
to make your way to the other end of the caverns. But what does it matter if
you make it out. Nothing matters...really...

rooms.Name: Ashnod's Altar
rooms.Description:
You are in a kind of pagan temple, complete with sacrificial altar. The
altar itself is made of wood, with a stone head-rest, and a metal bar to hold
down victims. You notice the two decent-sized holes in the altar, and the
permanent bloodstains around them attest to the grizzly means of execution.

rooms.Name: Planar Gate
rooms.Description:
You are standing at the bottom of a set of golden staris, leading up to the
biggest gate you've ever seen. The gate is carved of stone, and must be at
least 60 feet high. The gate is glowing, and you hope that doesn't mean that
something is about to come through. You truly fear what could fit through THAT
monstrous construction.

rooms.Name: Concordant Crossroads
rooms.Description:
You are now in what would appear to be a tropical paradise. Lush foliage and
brilliantly colored birds are all around you, and you feel just great! While
most jungle-like areas are nearly impassable, this one seems to clear a path
for you wherever you decide to go, making travel through here easier than
through even most open terrain.

rooms.Name: Raging River
rooms.Description:
You are standing on one of two cliffs that border on an out-of control river.
A tiny rope bridge spans the river, and you're certain you could make it
across, but crossing it during a battle would be suicide. You'd best decide
which side you want to be on before any combat starts. You'd hate to think of
what would happen to anything that fell into those surging waters.

rooms.Name: Tormod's Crypt
rooms.Description:
You enter the crypt through a dark entrance, and breath in the cold, damp
air that fills the crypt. In the gloom, you can make out a burial mound
(presumably containing the remains of Tormod), topped by a cross intersecting
a circle. Though there appears to be nothing alive in here, the place seems to
pulsate with the force of undeath.

rooms.Name: Arboria
rooms.Description:
You are in a jungle of living plants. Venus fly-traps that could swallow a
man whole loom all around, as well as many other, less-than-sedentary plants.
You notice that the plants are more hostile toward those who carry more magic,
and think that the safest course might be to remove your magical items. Then
you realize that the plants aren't trying to harm you, just block your way, as
if they were protecting someone.

rooms.Name: Timberline Ridge
rooms.Description:
You are in a mountainous area, at high altitude. Amid snow-covered pines and
other trees, you notice animal tracks. Higher up in the mountains, the trees
stop, as well as the animal tracks. You seem to be at the highest point of the
local ecosystem.

rooms.Name: Strip Mine
rooms.Description:
The ultimate in industrial destruction of the environment, all the natural
resources have been stripped from this land. The land has been removed in
tiers, to facilitate the removal of metal ores and coal, and whatever else
might once have been here. If there is anything left, someone will be back to
mine it.

rooms.Name: Safe Haven
rooms.Description:
At first glance this seems to just be a small hill like any other. Then,
hidden behind a bush, you see a little door, which you think you could crawl
through if you had to. Peeking inside, you see a comfortable little home,
seemingly unoccupied, but ready for any visitor who wants to stay here.
Whoever arranged for this place obviously meant for it to be a safe place to
stay for short periods of time.

rooms.Name: Taiga
rooms.Description:
This is a rather uninteresting terrain. It seems to be a coniferous forest
at the base of a mountain range. You catch the occasional glimpse of a moose
or bear, but it seems fairly quiet here, as if the battling wizards have seen
fit to leave this place alone.

rooms.Name: Library of Alexandria
rooms.Description:
Walking into this library you expect to see a traditional dusty old
collection of books. What you find is more akin to a palace. While there are
still books everywhere, the shelves are spread ccomfortably far apart, and
there are luxurious furnishings for the readers to enjoy. While the average
library caters to the academic, this one encourages learning by all, by making
it an all around enjoyable experience.

rooms.Name: Desert
rooms.Description:
Sand, sand, sand. The standard desert setup...the very model of a
traditional wasteland. The heat is just right to drain your strength and
dehydrate you, but not so high as to kill you outright. You wish you had a
camel, and you don't even like camels. Anything would be preferable to walking
across this whole place.

rooms.Name: Maze of Ith
rooms.Description:
What the?! Whoever built this maze seems to have neglected to build a way
out...Well, then again, that's what mazes are supposed to be like. Best be
running along and finding the way back out of here.

rooms.Name: Player Two's Graveyard
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what in game terms could be considered a discard pile.
From your point of view, it's a combination graveyard, junkyard.
   All around you are the twisted and mutilated remains of conjured creatures,
the shards of shattered artifacts, and the burnt out husks of used-up
enchanments (don't ask what the husk of an enchantment looks like).
   As you watch, one of the creatures begins to glow with a pale white light,
and begin to reform. In moments, it it whole again, and journeys off to heed
its master's call and live again.

rooms.Name: In Player Two's Hand
rooms.Description:
You are standing in mid-aid, behind a wall of giant cards, each depicting a
different spell. On the face of each card is a fanciful depiction of the
spell's effect, and some information about how the spell is used in the game.
You wonder what's behind the wall of cards, and decide to peek around it.
   You gasp in awe of the scene spread out beneath you. The landscape below is
twisted and mottled with terrains from every part of the multiverse, brought
here by the titanic magic of the players' spells. The boundaries of the lands
are quite distinct, as the landscape changes abruptly where one spell's effect
ends and another begins.
   Creatures of every description wander this surreal landscape, some
magnificent, others horrible. You are fascinated by the scene, and are
severely tempted to go down and explore.

rooms.Name: Player Two's Library
rooms.Description:
You are standing amid a huge pile if giant game cards. All the cards are
face-down, as if waiting for someone to draw one. Out of curiosity, you lift
the edge of one, and look at it. On the face of the card, there is a depiction
of a spell, and it's cost in mana, but it's unlike any mana you've ever heard
of. The mana is divided into different colors, and it takes a lot less of it
to cast spells than it does in the "real" world. Whoever is playing this game
seems to be some sort of deluded, wanna-be wizard.

rooms.Name: Oubliette
rooms.Description:
An oubliette is a place to put people to forget about them. Unlike a
dungeon, prisoners in an oubliette are never fed, never tortured...never
released. The rats here feast on the flesh of those who finally succumb to
mortality. Only the rats are here by choice.

rooms.Name: Greater Realm of Preservation
rooms.Description:
This is truly a greater realm. You are in a beautiful land, of green
grasses, and bright sunshine. You feels safe, and happy, and just plain great.
All around you are the angelic inhabitants of this realm. All of them greet
you warmly and offer their hospitality.

rooms.Name: On the Way To the Graveyard
rooms.Description:
Your mind boggles at this peek into the workings of the Celestial
Bureaucracy. The mutilated corpses of the dead are standing in line, waiting
to be sorted out into their respective afterlives. An unlucky few, under the
control of wizards at the time of their death, are doomed to return to their
master's graveyard, and await ressurection--or worse.

rooms.Name: Maze of Ith
rooms.Description:
Finally!!! This seems to be the way out of the infamous Maze of Ith. You
mentally make a note to never get yourself stuck in there again.

rooms.Name: Inside the Belly of the Leviathan
rooms.Description:
You cough and gasp for breath after being swallowed whole by the Leviathan.
Seawater and digestive juices cover you in a wet slime.
Speaking of digestive juices, you start to feel them eating away
at your skin, and seeping into your open wounds. If you don't
escape from here soon, you're going to die.

rooms.Name: The Entrance to a "Magic: the Gathering" Tournament
rooms.Description:
It seems that there is some sort of card game tournament going on at the
convention. All around you there are people rushing to sign up to enter and to
get to their first match. You see a sign-up table, where several officials
help people enter themselves in the tournament. Posted on the wall behind the
officials is a huge sign stating all the tournament rules. (Hint folks: READ
the SIGN).

ExtraDescs.Description:
Official Tournament Rules:
1) All players level 35 and under play in the junior division.
2) All players above level 35 play in the advanced division.
3) Summoning of creatures is permitted in designated areas.
4) Equipment lost to Atogs will not be refunded by tournament officials.
5) The decisio of the head judge is final.

To enter the tournament,type: "sign up"

rooms.Name: Player One's Library
rooms.Description:
You are standing amid a huge pile if giant game cards. All the cards are
face-down, as if waiting for someone to draw one. Out of curiosity, you lift
the edge of one, and look at it. On the face of the card, there is a depiction
of a spell, and it's cost in mana, but it's unlike any mana you've ever heard
of. The mana is divided into different colors, and it takes a lot less of it
to cast spells than it does in the "real" world. Whoever is playing this game
seems to be some sort of deluded, wanna-be wizard.

rooms.Name: In Player One's Hand
rooms.Description:
You are standing in mid-aid, behind a wall of giant cards, each depicting a
different spell. On the face of each card is a fanciful depiction of the
spell's effect, and some information about how the spell is used in the game.
You wonder what's behind the wall of cards, and decide to peek around it.
   You gasp in awe of the scene spread out beneath you. The landscape below is
twisted and mottled with terrains from every part of the multiverse, brought
here by the titanic magic of the players' spells. The boundaries of the lands
are quite distinct, as the landscape changes abruptly where one spell's effect
ends and another begins.
   Creatures of every description wander this surreal landscape, some
magnificent, others horrible. You are fascinated by the scene, and are
severely tempted to go down and explore.
   Far off in the distance, you notice another wall of cards hanging in the
air, with the reverse sides facing you.

rooms.Name: Player One's Graveyard
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what in game terms could be considered a discard pile.
From your point of view, it's a combination graveyard, junkyard.
   All around you are the twisted and mutilated remains of conjured creatures,
the shards of shattered artifacts, and the burnt out husks of used-up
enchanments (don't ask what the husk of an enchantment looks like).
   As you watch, one of the creatures begins to glow with a pale white light,
and begin to reform. In moments, it it whole again, and journeys off to heed
its master's call and live again.

rooms.Name: Seafarer's Quay
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what appears to be a stop-over for seamen. A little
inlet provides deep enough water for most merchant ships to dock at the piers
that dominate the waterfront. The place seems to be deserted, though it just
might be that the inhabitants aren't in the habit of conversing with every
armed adventurer who happens by.

rooms.Name: Mountain
rooms.Description:
From the heights of this majestic peak you can see the surrounding
countryside. Glaciers and Iceberg, Forests and Swamps, the variety of terrains
never ceases to amaze you. You notice many tracks along the mountain, trails,
and conclude that there must be some kind ofcivilization around...goblin
tracks don't just up and make themselves.

rooms.Name: Plateau
rooms.Description:
The plateau is like a mountain with the top flattened out. It makes for much
easier walking, but not nearly as good a view. No creatures seem to be native
to this area though, so you might be able to relax for a while.

rooms.Name: Plains
rooms.Description:
The plains are flat and empty. Home to cattle and small farmers, the plains
dry grasses are ideal for grazing. There is a wholesome quality to a place
like this...something not quite tangible. As you stare off into the distance,
you can't help but feel good about yourself.

rooms.Name: Island of Wak Wak
rooms.Description:
You are on a most curious island. The winged inhabitants seems to accept
your presence, hardly paying you any notice. You see orchards of trees that
bear the most curious fruit. The fruits are shaped like a woman's head. As you
wonder how they ever got the fruits to grow like that, you hear someone say
"Wak." When you turn to see who said it, there is no one there. You hear it
again, and realize that the fruits TALK!

rooms.Name: Island
rooms.Description:
The rythmic rush of the waves against the shore and the briny smell in the
air soothes your nerves. Looking out at the horizon, you see where this little
section of ocean ends, and the other lands conjured by the wizards begin.

rooms.Name: Elephant Graveyard
rooms.Description:
Shards of ivory that were once the tusks of mighty elephants mark this
gravesite as a holy place among those who revere and respect elephants. The
shamans tell tale that if the magic of this place is harnessed by a wizard, he
can heal even the most seriously wounded elephant from the brink of death.

rooms.Name: Tidal Flats
rooms.Description:
Your feet sink partway into the mud as you walk along land that spends half
its time beneath the waves. A ways off, you can hear the waves on the shore.
In a few hours, the tides will return,and cover the footprints that you are
leaving...and the land will forget you were ever here.

rooms.Name: Glaciers
rooms.Description:
You stand atop a mile-high block of ice. Cracks wide enough to swallow up
entire armies criss-cross this vast glacier. A cold wind blows across your
face, and you shiver at the bitter cold. What a bleak, inhospitable place.

rooms.Name: Icatian Town
rooms.Description:
What a quaint little town. This is the kind of place you read about in
storybooks. There are small wooden houses with thatched roofs, and barrels
outside to catch rainwater. A little stone bridge spans a stream that runs
through the town.

rooms.Name: Caribou Range
rooms.Description:
The land here ressembles an arctic tundra. The ground is white with frost,
but patches of hardy grasses poke through in places. That grass is the main
food supply for a vast herd of Caribou. Many arctic tribes follow the caribou
for food, and there is most likely a tribe nearby, unless they were separated
from the herd by the wizard's conjuring.

rooms.Name: Fortified Area
rooms.Description:
You're standing ouside a small fortress set on the tip of a penninsula.
There is a rocky hill around which the walls of the fortress are built, and
the walls themselves are arranged in three curtains, such that anyone invading
would have to pass all three walls to reach the tiny keep inside. In your
opinion, someone went a bit overboard in defending this place.

rooms.Name: Iceberg
rooms.Description:
You are standing on an Iceberg (well, at least on the tip of the iceberg).
It's chilly here, but not as cold as you might expect. You notice a part of
the iceberg glow red, and begin to melt, warming you a bit. What's why this
place it so warm! Some wizard is using it as a source of mana, drawing power
right out of the iceberg itself. This probably isn't even a real iceberg, but
a floating block of frozen mana.

rooms.Name: Hallowed Ground
rooms.Description:
You are standing in a snow forest, under an overcast sky. You see a humble
little house, with smoke coming out of the chimney. As you watch, the clouds
part slightly, and holy radiance bathes the house in its light. This must be
some kind of sanctified area.

rooms.Name: Snow Fortress
rooms.Description:
This "fortress" seems to be a gigantic mound of snow, with a huge wooden
door being the only entrance. At first this seems to be a ridiculous way to
defend a place, but then again, you can't really picture an invading army
breaking out snow-shovels to tear the place down, either.

rooms.Name: Runed Arch
rooms.Description:
This stone archway is carved with myriad runes, whose meaning you can't even
begin to discern. Through the arch you can see the huge eye of some creature
on the other side. Peeking around the arch, you can see that there isn't any
creature there. This arch must be some kind of interdimensional phase shift,
allowing parallel multiverses to...super...impose...you don't have a clue.

rooms.Name: Barl's Cage
rooms.Description:
You see a crude iron cage is suspended over a chasm by four heavy chains
attached to a framework. There is a small door to the cage, with a lock that's
rusted with age. You don't know what the cage is for, or why the mages decided
to bring it here. It doesn't look like it's sturdy enough to hold a dangerous
prisoner, though once it would have stood up to a great deal of punishment. It
must have some other use that is beyond you comprehension.

rooms.Name: Storm World
rooms.Description:
Entering this area isa truly like stepping into another world. You are
instantly struck by a gale force wind that nearly knocks you down. Storm
clouds whirl about you, even at ground level. You are occasionally zapped by
small jolts of lightning, but it seems that the magicks you carry offer some
protection, and you take no damage. You shudder to think what would happen if
you were unguarded.

rooms.Name: Skeleton Ship
rooms.Description:
You are on the deck of a skeleton ship that is sailing on a tiny patch of
water, smaller than most lakes. The hull of the ship is rotted out, but even
the holes in the hull don't sink the ship. The sails are in fair condition,
but tattered, their once bright red color faded with age. The crew of the ship
appear as skeletons, dressed in traditional seafarers' garb, but quite dead.
They seem to be content to ignore you as long as you let them run their ship.

rooms.Name: Serpent Generator
rooms.Description:
Before you is some weird sort of machine. It looks like a big sausage
grinder, except that instead of putting in meat...molten metal is pouring into
the top. You can't see where the molten metal is coming from, but you're
certain it's magical in origin. At the other end of the machine, the metal is
squeezed out into long cords of metal, that ressemble snakes. In fact, they
move like snakes, and hiss like snakes, too!!

rooms.Name: Drift of the Dead
rooms.Description:
You're once again in the icy cold. You climb a snowdrift to get a look
around at yoursurroundings, and you nearly retch. You notice that the
"snowdrift" you've been climbing is in fact a pile of frozen corpses and
skeletons that the storms have blow into a snowdrift. You can only hope that
you don't meet a similar fate in this harsh climate.

rooms.Name: Mudslide
rooms.Description:
At least you noticed it before it was too late. Due to heavy rains recently,
the hillsides here have become one huge mudslide. You see hapless cattle, and
the occasional goblin get sucked along down the hill with the mud. You don't
know what will become of them, but you doubt that without magical help they'll
ever get unstuck. If one of the wizards takes the trouble, a small amount of
his mana could most likely free them.

rooms.Name: Tourach's Gate
rooms.Description:
Nice spider. Someone with a taste for arachnids obviously built this gate.
The spider that stands over the gateway seems to be completely decorative.
Through the gate come a variety of disgusting creatures, obviously the result
of some kind of twisted magic (probably perpetrated the the spider-loving gate
builder).

rooms.Name: Glacial Crevasses
rooms.Description:
You see what must once have been a might glacier centuries ago. The ice now
has more cracks in it that most fields have blades of grass. Looking down into
out, you can see a pair of eyes staring back at you, the creature's body
obscured in the shadows of the crevasse. It appears that not everyone views
the glacier's sorry state as a tragedy. Some seem to think of it as a home.

rooms.Name: Elven Fortress
rooms.Description:
Walking through the forest, you remark at the size of the trees around you.
This is an old-growth forest in the extreme. Hearing a bird singing above you,
you look up and gape in amazement. There is a fortress built into the trees
over your head. You probably never would have noticed it if you weren't right
underneath it, so cleverly does it blend into the trees. This must be of elven
make, for no other civilized race has such rapport with the wilderness.

rooms.Name: Hot Springs
rooms.Description:
What a welcome relief. The blackened, rocky terrain gives way here to a pool
of steaming water. Despite the slightly sulferous smell, you're sorely tempted
to climb right in for a soothing bath. When was the last time you bathed,
anyway?

rooms.Name: Fountain of Youth
rooms.Description:
The enscription on the fountain reads: Fountain of Youth. Having heard the
legends of the Fountain of Youth, you'd have expected something a bit more
grand for the bringer of eternal life. There's no golden cup from which to
drink the blessed waters, no elaborate temple built around its grandeur. It's
just a stone fountain, with an ugly statue spouting water from its mouth.
Whoever found the way to grant eternal life through drinking water either had
no imagination, or a sick sense of humor.

rooms.Name: Avalanche
rooms.Description:
Be glad you weren't here when this happened. Too much snow must have built
up, and it all came tumbling down, destroying the land in the process. If
there is anything of any value under all that snow, you'll have to wait for a
melting to find it. It would take an army of dwarves with shovels to dig
through any decent amount of that snow.

rooms.Name: Bottomless Vault
rooms.Description:
You enter the vault through the massive steel door that someone
inadvertantly left open. Inside is a small stone ledge, and what looks to be a
bottomless pit (you have a keen eye for noticing things like that). Idly
kicking some gravel over the edge, you listen for it to hit the bottom.
Several times you hear the gravel scrape along the walls of the pit, but you
run out of patience before you hear anyting that sounds like it hitting the
bottom.

rooms.Name: Adventurers' Guildhouse
rooms.Description:
Judging by what you know of guilds, adventurers must be a hard-luck bunch.
While any respectable merchants' guild or theives' guild is a place of luxury,
built in the middle of a bustling town, the Adventurers' Guildhouse is a small
home along a trade way. Looking in through the window, the place looks
comfortable, but not opulent in any way. You get the feeling that this
"guildhouse" is more of a waystation for wandering adventurers than any kind
of meeting hall.

rooms.Name: Swamp
rooms.Description:
As you wade chest-deep through the murky, snake-invested watersof this
swamp, you wonder why any wizard would have wanted to bring this place here.
The answer: Swamps are one of the basic land types used for producing the mana
they draw upon for their powers. Swamps provide black mana, used for dark,
often self-destructive mana that many wizards shun.

rooms.Name: Bayou
rooms.Description:
A cross between a swamp and a forest, a bayou combines the murky waters of a
swamp with the healthy trees of a forest. Such mixed land-types are invaluable
to the wizards who conjure them. They give the wizard the ability to call upon
the powers of more than one type of mana, while only requiring them to conjure
up one land. Personally, you'd rather they favor tropical paradises when
deciding what lands they want around.

rooms.Name: Forest
rooms.Description:
Ahh...the sweet smell of the woods. Birds sing in the trees, and you
occasionally see a deer prancing through the forest. The forest is easy to
walk through, without a lot of undergrowth. You aren't bothered by any
mosquitoes, and don't notice any woodland predators about. Whichever wizard
brought this forest here only bothered to bring the pleasant parts.

rooms.Name: Diamond Valley
rooms.Description:
You're a millionaire!! Billionnaire!!! Trillionnaire!!! There are diamonds
everywhere in this valley. The ground is littered with them. You eagerly set
about trying to stuff all your containers full of them. You begin to get
annoyed, then frustrated, then exasperated by the fact that the diamonds won't
budge! Collapsing after a furious attempt to dislodge a particularly large
specimen, you notice that you can begin to see through the diamonds to the
barren ground beneath them. You also see a ghostly apparition of death that
does not approach you. It becomes clear to you that the illusion of the
diamonds was a lure to bring creatures heere for sacrifice...and that you were
spared...this time.

rooms.Name: Mountain Stronghold
rooms.Description:
You are at the base of a rocky mountain that is completely devoid of
vegetation, animals, and even snow. Atop the mountain is perched a fortress
with tall spires, and a stone wall around it. You don't see any path or easy
place to climb up the mountain, and for a moment you wonder how the tower got
built up there. You feel silly, thinking about all the weird places you've
been recently, and answer your own question: magic.

rooms.Name: Player Two's Graveyard
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what in game terms could be considered a discard pile.
From your point of view, it's a combination graveyard, junkyard.
   All around you are the twisted and mutilated remains of conjured creatures,
the shards of shattered artifacts, and the burnt out husks of used-up
enchanments (don't ask what the husk of an enchantment looks like).
   As you watch, one of the creatures begins to glow with a pale white light,
and begin to reform. In moments, it it whole again, and journeys off to heed
its master's call and live again.

rooms.Name: In Player Two's Hand
rooms.Description:
You are standing in mid-aid, behind a wall of giant cards, each depicting a
different spell. On the face of each card is a fanciful depiction of the
spell's effect, and some information about how the spell is used in the game.
You wonder what's behind the wall of cards, and decide to peek around it.
   You gasp in awe of the scene spread out beneath you. The landscape below is
twisted and mottled with terrains from every part of the multiverse, brought
here by the titanic magic of the players' spells. The boundaries of the lands
are quite distinct, as the landscape changes abruptly where one spell's effect
ends and another begins.
  Creatures of every description wander this surreal landscape, some
magnificent, others horrible. You are fascinated by the scene, and are
severely tempted to go down and explore.
   Far off in the distance, you notice another wall of cards hanging in the
air, with the reverse sides facing you.

rooms.Name: Player Two's Library
rooms.Description:
You are standing in what in game terms could be considered a discard pile.
From your point of view, it's a combination graveyard, junkyard.
   All around you are the twisted and mutilated remains of conjured creatures,
the shards of shattered artifacts, and the burnt out husks of used-up
enchanments (don't ask what the husk of an enchantment looks like).
   As you watch, one of the creatures begins to glow with a pale white light,
and begin to reform. In moments, it it whole again, and journeys off to heed
its master's call and live again.

rooms.Name: Goblin Shrine
rooms.Description:
Only goblins would be stupid enough to light a bonfire underground. It looks
like they are holding some sort of pagan ceremony here. Goblins are dancing
around the fire (and occasionally stumbling into it) and screaming like
lunatics. It would be quite a fearsome sight to behold if the goblins weren't
two feet shorter than you.

rooms.Name: Goblin Caves
rooms.Description:
You have to hunch over to walk through these caves. The stench of countless
generations of goblin inhabitation make the area almost intolerable. You pass
by unidentifiable piles of offal, and the occasional corpse of a former
goblin. All in all, the trip would be much more pleasant if you'd thought to
bring a garden hose and a gas mask.

rooms.Name: Goblin Warrens
rooms.Description:
This seems to be the goblins main living area. You get the clue from the
incredible number or tiny goblin children running around everywhere. Support
beams reinforce tunnels that branch off in all directions to the goblins'
individual quarters, but goblin engineering prowess doesn't give you any
confidence in their stability. In all the chaos of the children running
around, and the female goblins trying to round them up, the goblins hardly
notice you.

rooms.Name: Breeding Pit
rooms.Description:
Ewww!! Whatever that pool of slop in the middle of the room is, you don't
want to know. You can see through the murky fluid that there is something
under there, moving around. Alot of somethings, in fact. On the shores of this
disgusting pond are hideous creatures, no doubt the result of the swill in
that pool. From the looks of these monstrosities, killing them would be a
favor.

rooms.Name: On the Beach
rooms.Description:
On these sands shoes are a must during the day and just perfect at night.
Volley ball net has been setup for recreation as well as a B-ball court
to the west. To the east you see hammoc set between two trees in the 
shade.

Before you stand a two tone grey and red brick dream. A solid redwood door
blocks the entrance way, with purple hazed colored roses going on each side
This dream sits on 2 and a half mile of private beeach,and about 80 feet
from the crystal blue waters.

rooms.Name: Inside Lord Therons' Beach House
rooms.Description:
As you look about you , you cant help but to notice the Old Japaneese Art
about the room. To your left you see a vase from the Ming dynasty. Upon
the wall are painting of great battles fouhgt,and of course the loved cla
DOGs Shooting Pool. theres a 56inch console television with cables att
placed aginst the far wall. You also can see the beach from the living room
window.

rooms.Name: Patio
rooms.Description:
From this window you can see Ocean for mile out. Golden tan beach hazes the 
sight with the reflection of the sun gleaming off it. Lounge and lawn chairs
are setting about under the canopy with a warm breeze flowing on you
